BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for meticulous route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to east to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally in the high Alpine regions. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. From starting zones where no previous releases have taken place in particular the avalanches can in isolated cases reach large size. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes below approximately 2700 m, as well as on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind will transport the fresh and old snow significantly. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain. The near-surface layers of the snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed especially above approximately 2300 m. They are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack can be released even by individual winter sport participants on wind-loaded slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

On wind-loaded slopes dry loose snow avalanches are possible above approximately 2300 m, in particular in the vicinity of peaks, especially in case of releases originating from very steep starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. Small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2300 m, especially on very steep sunny slopes.
In addition in areas not adjacent to ridgelines, individual medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2200 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen. Until Friday the wind will be strong over a wide area.
Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Artificially triggered avalanches and stability tests confirm the complex avalanche situation in particular in the regions exposed to substantial precipitation.

The weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers on Wednesday in particular on very steep sunny slopes, in particular below approximately 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger will persist. The extensive wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are mostly small but in some cases prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: More recent wind slabs can still be released in some cases in particular on northwest to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Mostly avalanches are only small. Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh wind slabs are in some cases still prone to triggering at elevated altitudes.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to significant moistening of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes, this also applies on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures the snow drift accumulations stabilised on Wednesday. These conditions will bring about a decrease in the danger of dry avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Little snow fell on Monday in some localities. More recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and the strong to storm force northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form on Thursday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Adjacent to ridgelines the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. These are to be avoided in particular in steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable.
The wind will transport the loosely bonded old snow. Wind slabs can in isolated cases be released by small loads. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible.
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a settling of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Along the border with France the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, clearly visible wind slabs will form in particular along the border with France. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2500 m. More recent wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep north, east and southeast facing slopes above approximately 2400 m, especially at their margins. As a consequence of warming during the day individual small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible below approximately 3000 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind has transported some snow. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 3000 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs above approximately 2000 m. The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can still in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the day progresses as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a gradual increase in the avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes above the tree line.
Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural avalanches are possible. The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Along the border with France the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes easily released wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to east facing aspects above approximately 2500 m, especially at their margins. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. These are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain. As a consequence of warming during the day small and medium-sized dry and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 3000 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Up to 5 cm of snow has fallen. The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force wind from northwesterly directions, mostly shallow wind slabs formed. They are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
In particular on wind-loaded slopes mostly small dry loose snow avalanches are possible above approximately 2300 m, in particular in the vicinity of peaks.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2300 m, especially on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities 0 to 10 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2200 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen. Until Friday the wind will be strong over a wide area. As a consequence of a strong to storm force northwesterly wind, rather small wind slabs formed during the night. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
The weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers on Wednesday in particular on very steep sunny slopes, in particular below approximately 2300 m.
The new snow of last week has bonded well with the old snowpack in all aspects.
The upper section of the snowpack is not distinctly layered.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 1900 m less snow than usual is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from northwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form on north and east facing slopes. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are a little more prevalent and exist in all aspects. The avalanche prone locations are and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.

More gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
On extremely steep slopes individual mostly small wet loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
North of the Inn 5 to 15 cm of snow has fallen since Monday. Less snow than expected has fallen in the other regions.
Up to 5 cm of snow will fall until the early morning. Up to high altitudes rain will fall.
The storm force wind will transport the fresh and old snow. The fresh wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The weather conditions will give rise to significant moistening of the snowpack especially at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: 10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. As a consequence of snowfall and the strong northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: At high altitude and in gullies and bowls individual small avalanches are possible. These can be released by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: At intermediate and high altitudes a little snow is lying. The sometimes strong wind has transported some snow. The wind slabs are shallow. These are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and generally at high altitudes. The weather conditions will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack also at high altitude.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on steep shady slopes. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The mostly small wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of warming during the day mostly small avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and the strong to storm force northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form on Thursday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. In particular in the south and at the base of rock walls mostly small moist loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural avalanche activity will increase. Moist avalanches can occur naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will become generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Avalanches are not to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches are not to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Above approximately 1400 m only a little snow is lying. The weather conditions will give rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack also at high altitude.
